div.p: Words are included in the Latin Glossary if they are not found with the required sense in the Oxford Latin Dictionary (OLD), as supplemented where appropriate by the Dictionary of Medieval Latin from British Sources (DML). Adverbs that are formed regularly from adjectives found in the OLD and DML are not included. Words with unusual spellings have been not been included if they are treated in the text as scribal errors and footnoted, or if they are the result of the following common spelling variations alone:
c for t before i
cc for ct before i
-d for -t in final position
e for ae or oe
ff- for f- in initial position
addition or omission of h
variation between i and e or ar and er in medial positions, especially before another vowel
variation between de- and di- as a prefix
n for m before another nasal or a stop (eg, inp- for imp-)
intrusion of p in consonant clusters mm, mn, ms, or mt
doubling of single consonants or vice versa

Where the same word occurs in spellings which differ according to the list above, the most common spelling is treated as standard and used for the headword. We have conformed to the practice of the OLD as regards 'i/j' and 'u/v' variation: in this glossary only the letter forms 'i' and 'u' are used. If a noun of the first declension appears only with a genitive singular in '-ae,' that spelling is used in the head form, otherwise the ML '-e' is used.

Nouns are listed by nominative, genitive, and gender; adjectives by the endings of the nominative singular or, in the case of adjectives of one ending, by the nominative and genitive; verbs by their principal parts.

Words have been included in the Anglo-French Glossary if they are not found with the required sense in either the Collins-Robert French Dictionary or in the Anglo-Norman Dictionary Online or cannot be easily found there in the spelling in which they occur in the text. Words with unusual spellings have been not been included if they are treated in the text as scribal errors and footnoted, or if they are the result of the following common spelling variations alone:
doubling of single consonants
singling of double consonants
elision of preceding de, la, le, or ne with words beginning with a vowel or h
variability of vowel or diphthongs preceding -r (eg, our for er, ir for er)
omission or addition of h in initial position
au for a or al
addition or omission of final e
-ent for -ant in final position and vice versa
-es for -ez or vice versa in final position
oe or oi for e or ei
ou for o
-tz or -z for -s or -ce in final position
y for i

Words, including place names and other proper names, easily recognizable from the English are not glossed (eg, 'Hector de troyes,' 'hire'). Nouns are designated n f (feminine), n m (masculine), or n where the gender cannot be determined from context.

Words have been included in the English Glossary if they are not found with the required sense in the Oxford English Dictionary Online (OEDO) or cannot be easily found there in the spelling in which they appear in the text. Words with unusual spellings have not been included if they have been treated in the text as scribal errors and footnoted, or if they are the result of the following common spelling variations alone:
doubling of single consonants and vice versa
a/ai/ay
a/au
ar/er
c/s
ea/e/ei
e/i
ie/e(e)
i/j
i/y
oa/o/oo
o/ou
o/u
s/z
sch/sh
u/v
y- in initial position for th or þ
presence or absence of final -e
medial d for th (eg, fader for father)
plurals ending in -n (eg, shoon for shoes)
elision of the with words beginning with a vowel or h (thandes for the hands)
fusion of indefinite article with following noun or adjective (eg, aboke for a book)

The capitalization of headwords conforms to modern usage. A word appearing in several noteworthy spellings is normally entered under the one most often found in the text or else – when two spellings are equally or nearly equally common – under the one nearer modern usage, but a marginally less common spelling may be preferred to keep related forms together in the entry order of the glossary. Other spellings are entered in their alphabetical places and cross-referenced to the main entry. In the alphabetical order of the glossary 'þ' follows 't' and 'ȝ' follows 'y.' Where the definition repeats the headword in a different spelling, the latter is normally the entry spelling in OEDO and further information can be found there. When that form is itself an archaism or ambiguous, a further brief definition usually follows. Any further citation of an authority or other succinct account of the glossarian's reasoning appears within square brackets at the end of the entry.

entry.sense: St Bettelin (dates unknown), patron of Stafford

boy bishop, a boy, originally a choirboy in a cathedral or other collegiate church or a student in an almonry school, chosen to act as a mock bishop in liturgical and other observances on the feast of St Nicholas or of the Holy Innocents
entertainment, ‘play,’ of an unspecified kind, not necessarily dramatic; [see also DML ludus]
of or pertaining to St Michael;
of or pertaining to a parish
promoted, used of a proceeding against a person in a church court moved or initiated by someone other than the court itself or a person authorized to make presentment
in CL, an actor; sense widening in ML, here an entertainer, or performer of some kind unspecified; [see histrio DML, OLD]

entry.form: bouche in phr estre a bouche en court, estre a bouche de court
entry.sense: to have an allowance for food; [see AND bouche]
charger, horse ridden in charging a combatant, [AND destrer]

div.entry: plerrafut 3 plwe need "fut" added to the abbreviation list--> of plaisir [AND]

entry.sense: the hundred of Amounderness in Lancashire
anent, before, in the sight of [OEDO anent prep II]
raised or levied (money, troops, etc.) [OEDO araise v 3]; aresed; arreised; arreysed
Austen Friary in Stafford; the fryers
part of a fool's attire, a baton used as a mock emblem of office [OEDO bauble n 4]
to remain somewhere for a long period of time (?)
the Broad Eye, a windmill in Stafford; broadey
cap-making, the cap maker's trade [OEDO capping n 2]; cappinge
chaudon, a kind of sauce containing chopped entrails
St Crispin's Day; chryspany day; chryspian day; chryspiane day; crispiany daie; cryspyany day
course, the pursuit of game [OEDO course n 7.a] coorsse
of little or no account, ordinary; in phrcoursse moneypetty cash (?) [OEDO coarse adj 1.a, b] [MED cours adj (a)
curl; here, possibly a wig (?) [OEDO curle v.1 2]
distrain, to constrain or punish a person by seizing their goods [OEDO distrainvII.7.a]; distreane; distreine
essoined, to be excused or exonerated [OEDO essoin v 2]
estreated, to extract a fine, bail, or forfeiture and give it to an exchequer; loosely, to exact a fine or enforce a forfeiture [OEDO estreat v 1, 2]
flat-cap, one who wears a flat cap; perhaps here an apprentice (?) [OEDflat-capn2]
gear, here equipment used in the performance of a play
likely an abbreviation of Wolverhampton hamptonn
harness, gear, equipment; esp. military equipment or accoutrement [OEDharnessn2.a]; harnese, harnesse
knight harbinger, a title given to one responsible for purveying lodgings for an army, royal procession, etc., or for setting up a campground
heaving, the Easter custom of lifting members of the opposite sex into the air; heyveng, heywyng, heywynge

hobby-horse, a figure of a horse made of wicker or other light material worn about the waist by a performer, typically at a morris dance; hobbe horsse, hobbey horse, hobbie horse, hobbiehorse, hobbihorse, hobbyhorse, hobby horsse, hobbyhorsse, hoby horse, hobyhorse,
St John's Day, possibly in error for 'Iohn' (?)
empanel, a list of members of a jury [OEDempaneln]
jerks; thrusts, pushes, pulls, or twists with sudden movements [OEDjerkv.12.a]
liberal arts, the branches of learning forming the trivium (grammar, logic, rhetoric) and quadrivium (arithmetic, geometry, music, astronomy) in medieval education [OEDsciencen3.a]
moot hall, a town hall, council chamber, or courtroom
an act of misdemeanour, an actionable offense of misconduct committed by a misdemeanant [OEDmisdemeanantn1]
pottle; as a unit of capacity, equal to half a gallon
pied coat, a fool's coat, typically a coat with variegated colour [OEDpiedadjA.1.b and S2]
likely one of several hamlets known as Ridware: Pipe Ridware, Mavesyn Ridware, or Hamstall Ridware
attendant responsible for guiding or conducting people to the Great Chamber, Presence Chamber, or other chamber for audience [OEDshowv16]
sheet roll (?), a record or list [OEDrolln.1I.1.a, b]
summer game; a festival, sport, or entertainment held in the summer
state body, the collective population of a town, city, state, etc.; esp. that portion of the population involved in its government [OEDbodyn13.a]
stoops, pillars or posts used by performers (?) [OEDstoopn.11.a]
surplice; a garment worn to a dance
usually a keyed musical instrument with plural form refering to one instrument, but here possibly the keyboard(s) to an organ (?)
household officials, servants, or attendants charged with procuring drink [OEDyeomannC3.a]
household officials, servants, or attendants charged with maintaining a pantry, or with providing or serving food and drink [OEDyeomannC3.a]
